etymologies: mid 19th century. Probably from Irish regional (chiefly Aran) pampúta, probably from Dutch pampoesje indoor slipper (perhaps altered after -tje, diminutive suffix; compare German regional (Low German) Pampuschen, plural) or its etymon Javanese †pampus from early modern Persian pāpōš Compare babouche. Perhaps compare also pump

definitions: A kind of sandal or moccasin of untanned cowhide or sealskin sewn together and tied across the instep, traditionally worn by the inhabitants of the Aran Islands. Usually in plural.
